pageSummaryWhat: We have set this page up in memory of our dear dad
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

As many of you will know, our lovely dad has recently died suddenly and unexpectedly. This will leave a huge void in so many people's lives including ours. 

Those who knew him will know that he lived to help others, and that he also hated to see things go to waste. In Dad's Will, he left instructions that in the event of his death, he would like family-only flowers and that anyone who wished to do so, could leave a donation in his memory. 

Typically, Dad chose Macmillan Cancer Support - not because he had been diagnosed with cancer himself - but because the Macmillan Nurses had been a tremendous support for Mum, when she had terminal cancer in 1999. Since then, the charity remained a cause that was very close to his heart so to the end, he wanted to help others.

We're sure he would appreciate any donation in his memory - it would be such a perfect and fitting way for such a wonderful man to be remembered.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you so much.

Gill, Sue and Tony Woods xxx

story:
Back in January, a good friend of mine told me about a trio of Charity walk's he was planning in support of a family member who was diagnosed with Cancer just before Christmas.

Wanting to support with more than just a donation, I decided that I would offer to walk with him & his partner when they travel up to Northumberland.

What began as an offer of moral support became a realisation that I could actually do so much more by joining them in fund raising, not just for their family member, but for everyone affected by this horrible disease.

It is a harrowing fact that we will all be affected by Cancer in our lifetime albeit personally or with friends and family; my small part in supporting everyone affected will take place on the 17th July 2021 when I will be walking 26 miles in Northumberland for Macmillan Cancer Support.

The money we are aiming to raise is vital for Macmillan to continue the incredible work they do for people living with cancer across the UK so if you are able to donate, it will go a long way to helping so many people who really need it.

Tom

story:
On sat 10 July, I am taking part in the race to the stones 100k (62 miles) ultra marathon to raise money for the British heart foundation. Coronary heart disease is now the leading cause of death world wide. 7.6 million people in the UK are living with heart and circulatory disease and there are 450 deaths every day in the UK from heart attacks, and 1 stroke every 5 minutes. To raise money for this cause I’m attempting to do 2.5 marathons in a day. The race to the stones follows the trail from Lewknor passed Waylands Smithy, Uffington Whitehorse and Barbury Castle before reaching the iconic ancient stone circle at Avebury. Simon.

story:
Thanks for visiting our page. We are raising money for the British Heart Foundation and we'd be immensely grateful for your support. 

As an In-house Legal Team at Secure Trust Bank plc, we were collectively planning a charity challenge in January this year to raise money for a good cause and to get us all outside and moving! We were all going to join in with some promising to run miles and miles each week, and others, like Alan our General Counsel, committing to walking a couple of miles a week. We each had a different target but a challenge for all nevertheless.  That plan was put on hold when very sadly, and very suddenly Alan died just before Christmas. As a team we are re-grouping with some more colleagues and are now even more committed to raising money for two good causes we know Alan would have wholeheartedly supported: the British Heart Foundation and Dementia UK. We are determined to get outside, no matter the weather, and get active to get those miles logged, all whilst remembering Alan who we all miss daily. 

The original plan was to run, cycle or walk the distance between the three offices the STB lawyers work at, which was about 150 miles but we have now increased our target to 500 miles.  Please support us in our challenge and consider donating to one of the nominated charities.

Inna illahi wa inna ilayhi Rajioon 

2nd April 1955 - 26th March 2016

Always in our hearts 🤍


My late father passed due to a lung disease (Pulmonary Hypertension) and he had a heart operation in his childhood  knowing what I know now due to his passing almost 5 years ago is the lack of knowledge I had about lung disease and the types of diseases out there! What I learnt during his time at the heart and lung hospital in London back in January 2016 was that there are a whole array of lung diseases which I hadn’t even heard of and unfortunately they said there was nothing that they could do for him as too much water had entered his lungs and there was very little (2%) functionality left from that organ. 

It’s coming up to his 5th year death anniversary so in his memory I wanted to do something that will help others in a difficult position. He was a fighter and he went on until the very end, he walked until his body could no longer walk! He was my rock and he always encouraged me to be healthy because of what he went through! I want to make him proud!

Anyone who’s lost their loved ones due to this pandemic my heart goes out to you! I pray that we’re all protected from this vicious disease!

I will be giving up chocolate for the whole month of March! Now this is a challenge for me, he knew how much of a chocoholic I am and my close family and friends know how much I’m obsessed with anything chocolate! Moving forward- I can do this for him, myself and my children! Please donate generously! Remember that ‘Charity does not decrease your wealth’

Thank you for taking time in reading this, I appreciate every one of you!


Much love Zoy xox

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
Due to the pandemic, the BHF have been forced to cut their 2020 research budget in half. This charity helps create real life solutions to help those with heart and circulatory conditions.   

The motivation to keep going with the Dechox throughout March is that I have family and close friends who need more to be done in the fight for a better quality of life. 

It's not just me who has those they care about, trying to manage such a condition. So for the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
So 4 weeks today I'll be enjoying my last bit of chocolate, because from Monday 1st March right until 31st March I'm going to take part in The British Heart Foundation's annual March dechox... Yep, I'll be giving up chocolate, and anything with chocolate on it or in it, for 1 whole month!

Might sounds easy for some, but anyone who knows me will know this will be a huge thing for me, as I'm an emotional eater with a massive sweet tooth!! Even when I'm on a diet, I still eat chocolate every single day! 

So I thought why not do this, not only to properly challenge myself, but also to raise money for a brilliant charity 😊

If you'd like to sponsor me, you can do so here on this page & I promise I won't let you down 😊🥰 And don't worry, once 1st March comes all chocolate will be removed from the house and I'm sure Ian will be keeping a very close eye on my every move! 😂🙈

 Also my Grandad who I sadly never met, passed away of heart disease. And my Nana Peggy, who we miss so much after she passed away a couple of months ago, was always a supporter of the charity since grandad passed away, so I'm doing this in both their memories too.

story:
Thank you for following the link. I’m taking part in the Royal Parks Half Marathon for the British Heart Foundation and I’d be grateful your support. 

Heart conditions have affected people in my family, so the BHF’s cause is very important to me. 

I’ll also list some facts relating to the subject:

  • Heart and circulatory diseases cause more than a quarter of all deaths in the UK, that’s more than 160,000 deaths each year – an average of 450 deaths each day or one every three minutes in the UK. To put this into perspective, the population of Oxford is 154,600,

  • There are around 7.6 million people living with heart and circulatory disease in the UK: 4 million men and 3.6 million women.

  • Around 1.4 million people alive in the UK today have survived a heart attack and around 900,000 people in the UK are living with heart failure

  • £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist 

  • Coronary heart disease is the single biggest killer worldwide

Since the establishment of the British Heart Foundation, the annual number of deaths related to heart and circulatory diseases in the UK has halved - please help me reach my goal and help prevent even more early deaths.

Love you always, 🙏🏼

We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
pageSummary: NA
story:
The RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown. Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives has not stopped.

Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds has been limited. The average lifeboat station in the North West costs £136,000 a year to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income due to the Coronavirus. We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running.

All along the North West coast from Silloth to West Kirby, we will always be there to keep you and your loved ones safe, on our watch, there will be no preventable deaths on the North West coast. Please help us fulfil that mission.

story:
Last weekend I watched Simon Reeve’s ‘Incredible Journeys’, in the first episodes I have learnt how in Bangladesh and other countries there are children younger than me living in poverty and living on the streets.  They do anything to earn money for their family.  In the programme children as young as 4 were picking pieces of glass out heaps of rubbish and taking them to the glass factories where 10 year olds were working at a hot furnace making glass bottles. They earned the equivalent of 30p for one days’ work.  The adults there said that foreigners had come and tried to take the children out of work but without work they had no money and their situation became worse.  This is where Unicef comes in. They have set up centres for working children. These centres provide a free lunch, shower, a safe place to socialise with their friends and a basic education. 

This inspirational programme made me wonder how I can help people like this. I have come up with a challenge to try and raise money for Unicef. I have decided to run 100 kilometres in February (25k per week, not including walking).  I am hoping that people will sponsor me for completing this running challenge so I can raise as much money as possible for Unicef.  Not only will my running get better, children’s lives will get better.
